comments:
Hello,

I'm not sure if I should submit this against the "Core" component. Please 
forward it to the correct component owner.

Here's my configuration:
I'm using Eclipse v2.1 (Build id: 200302270800) on Win 2000 with Sun's JDK 
1.4.1_02.

I'm seeing a weird error message. After posting a question to "eclipse.tools" 
about this message I received a response from Jared Burns who said I should 
report this as a bug.

Do this to reproduce:


1. Navigate the menu options,  "Run | External Tools | External Tools..."

2. Click on the "Program" item under "Configurations" and click the "New" 
button.

3. In the "Location" field enter the name of some program or batch file. It's 
not important what you enter, just so it can be run.

4. Make sure "Run tool in background" is NOT checked.

5. Click on the "Refresh" tab and select the "Refresh resources after running 
tool" checkbox. When you do this the ${working_set} scope variable should 
automatically be selected. In my configuration I do not have any "working sets" 
defined. I think you should do the same to reproduce this experience. In other 
words, make sure you don't have any working sets defined.

6. Now click on one of the other scope variables (such as ${workspace}). Now 
click back onto ${working_set}. In my system I now see a new "${working_set}" 
window which appears below the "scope variable" window. But in order to make 
this window appear it was necessary to click off the ${working_set} item and 
then click back on it.

7. Finally, (assuming ${working_set} is selected and you have no working sets 
defined) if you click the "Run" button you should see a dialog message that 
reads, "An error occurred attempting to expand the variable working_set. No 
working set defined."


The first thing I want to mention is that this dialog only seems to occur if 
the "Run tool in background" option (described in step 4) is not checked. If 
this option is checked the dialog doesn't appear. That seems weird and 
inconsistent. If a "working set" is required shouldn't it be required 
regardless of whether or not the tool is run in the background?

The second thing is that, in my opinion, the error message was very cryptic. I 
didn't understand what it was trying to tell me.

Finally, why was it necessary to click off the ${working_set} variable and then 
click back onto it (described in step 6) in order to make the "${working_set}" 
window appear?

If you need any further information please (inluding screen shots) feel free to 
contact me. 

Thanks

>>The first thing I want to mention is that this dialog only seems to occur if 
>>the "Run tool in background" option (described in step 4) is not checked. If 
>>this option is checked the dialog doesn't appear. That seems weird and 
>>inconsistent. If a "working set" is required shouldn't it be required 
>>regardless of whether or not the tool is run in the background?

We have a general problem of error reporting when the tool is run in the 
background. Was anything reported to your .log file?

>>The second thing is that, in my opinion, the error message was very cryptic. 
>>I didn't understand what it was trying to tell me.

We should work on improving this

>>Finally, why was it necessary to click off the ${working_set} variable and 
>>then click back onto it (described in step 6) in order to make 
>>the "${working_set}" window appear?

See bug 32700

Well, yes, there was something reporting to the .log file, which I'll describe 
in a moment. Just to make sure you understand, the tool itself is not reporting 
an error. Eclipse is reporting the error about the ${working_set} variable, but 
the error is reported only if the tool is *not* run in the background.

The error reported in the .log file is shown below. 

!ENTRY org.eclipse.debug.ui 4 120 Mar 08, 2003 12:09:04.442
!MESSAGE Error logged from Debug UI: 
!STACK 1
org.eclipse.core.runtime.CoreException: An error occurred attempting to expand 
the variable working_set. No working set specified.
	at 
org.eclipse.ui.externaltools.internal.variable.DefaultVariableExpander.throwExpa
nsionException(DefaultVariableExpander.java:52)
	at 
org.eclipse.ui.externaltools.internal.variable.WorkingSetExpander.getResources
(WorkingSetExpander.java:41)
	at 
org.eclipse.ui.externaltools.internal.launchConfigurations.ExternalToolsUtil.ref
reshResources(ExternalToolsUtil.java:252)
	at 
org.eclipse.ui.externaltools.internal.program.launchConfigurations.ProgramLaunch
Delegate.launch(ProgramLaunchDelegate.java:133)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch
(LaunchConfiguration.java:151)
	at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin.buildAndLaunch
(DebugUIPlugin.java:668)
	at org.eclipse.debug.ui.DebugUITools.buildAndLaunch
(DebugUITools.java:537)
	at org.eclipse.debug.ui.DebugUITools$2.run(DebugUITools.java:486)
	at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run
(ModalContext.java:95)
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui.externaltools 4 0 Mar 08, 2003 12:09:04.442
!MESSAGE An error occurred attempting to expand the variable working_set. No 
working set specified.

Right, when the tool is run in the background we have not created the 
infrastructure to report into the UI via a dialog.  Logging to the .log is the 
current mechanism that the tool uses (which needs to be improved).

Deferred to post 2.1.

traces.message: An error occurred attempting to expand  the variable working_set. No working set specified.
